Train-Id1666.text: The snow gods have been extra kind to Utah, Tahoe, and Jackson Hole over the last few days, with multiple ski areas and resorts recording over 20 inches.

Train-Id1742.text: AUSTIN, Texas -- It might be slow but temperatures are finally dropping in what has been the fifth longest heat wave in Austin history.

Dev-Id217.text: THE Met Office has issued a severe weather warning for today, as flash floods and intense downpours are expected to cause disruption for the majority of England and Wales.

Dev-Id218.text: Britain will be lashed by thunderstorms and 50mph winds as remnants of Hurricane Humberto blows in from the Atlantic.

Dev-Id219.text: Intense downpours and strong gusty winds will batter the country for the whole of today - spreading from the south coast all the way up to Newcastle.

Weather compass direction: from the south coast all the way up to Newcastle

Dev-Id222.text: Met Office meteorologist Luke Miall said: "We could see 20mm to 40 mm of rain within nine hours and possibly the worst-case scenario is of 70mm in some spots."

Dev-Id223.text: Mr Miall also said that despite the wet weather, pockets of sunshine over the following days could see temperatures in the low 20s - which is slightly warmer than normal for the time of year.

Dev-Id224.text: Along with the three inch - downpour, there is the possibility of the odd rumble of thunder in some areas on Tuesday in contrast to recent dry days and sunshine.

Dev-Id225.text: The severe weather warning issued by the Met Office will last until 11pm on Tuesday - however, the wet weather is expected to continue until Thursday.

Dev-Id226.text: Areas affected by the intense deluge and windy weather are also expected to flood - with a particular warning for smaller communities which may be cut off by overflowing roads.

Dev-Id227.text: The tail-end of Hurricane Humberto will bring misery to the UK - as the tropical cyclone brings a week of wet weather and thunderstorms to the majority of the country.

Test-Id35.text: WEATHER forecasters have said that while Brits may have got off to a frosty start this Valentine’s Day, the sun will be sweeping in, sending temperatures across the UK soaring this afternoon.

Test-Id37.text: Scotland will see its warmest Valentine’s Day for 21 years, with the Met Office forecasting 16C in northern areas – 11C above average.

Test-Id39.text: He said: “Some of us could reach 15C or 16C, really quite exceptional for this time of year.”

Test-Id40.text: Mr Keates said the UK would wake up to a frosty morning and the fog could take until mid-late morning to clear across England and Wales.
